On Mon, 11 Oct 2004 00:13:27 +0100, Colin Green <cgreen@...> wrote:
> This all goes back to a discussion a while ago when it
> transpired that Derek And Philip's ANJI code was using a different
> scheme, I think due to some ambiguous wording in one of the NEAT
> papers. 

Yeah, our mutation rates are basically the rate at which new
topological mutations arise among all possible locations where a legal
mutation could occur (e.g., since add node mutations can only occur
where there are existing connections, if there are 1000 connections in
the population, with an add node mutation rate of 0.01 you'll get 10
new node mutations).  The NEAT mutation rate indicates the probability
of a given individual being mutated.

We've actually done a little testing both ways, and it doesn't appear
to make much of a difference...which I think tends to confirm that
NEAT is overall a very robust algorithm.

Just as when we added a mutation to delete connections, we observed
little change in performance across runs (the big difference was the
size of the resulting champion networks).

> So I have started devising a GA for searching connection mutaion
> schemes. SharpNEAT is (fingers crossed) currently geared up for this
> type of meta-GA because I already have all of the NEAT parameters
> encapsulated in a NeatParameters class that is passed into the NEAT
> algorithm, which itself is encapsulated in an EvolutionAlgorithm class.

Well good luck with that, and let us know how it turns out. :)

It's interesting, as Yuri points out, you've got parameters for your
meta-mutations, which I suppose you could have a meta-mutation system
for as well.  And one for that one...it's turtles all the way down!

Derek
